PostValue.explanation: This is an operational announcement soliciting user feedback for Forum strategy. It could modestly affect how the EA Forum is run (features, moderation, priorities) and therefore influence community discourse and CEA resource allocation, but it isn't foundational to EA theory or major cause decisions. For the wider world it is essentially irrelevant.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No evidence up to my 2024-06 knowledge cutoff of a notable author named Sarah Cheng within the Effective Altruism/rationalist community or as a public figure. The name appears common and could be a private or pseudonymous individual; please supply works or context for a more accurate assessment.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is clear, friendly, and provides the key details readers need: purpose, dates, estimated time, that questions are optional, who it’s for, and why responses matter. It has a straightforward call to action and useful links/footnotes. Minor weaknesses: a few small redundancies (e.g. reiterating why responses matter), slightly cluttered footnote formatting, and the actual survey link/button isn't visible in the excerpt — tightening wording and simplifying footnotes would make it a bit more concise.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is a routine announcement for an annual user survey. The core idea — asking users to complete an optional survey to inform platform strategy — is extremely common both within the EA community and across organizations. The only mildly specific details (timing, optional questions, browser-save feature, use for Forum strategy) are procedural and not conceptually novel.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The post presents a straightforward, mostly logical case for running the survey (surveys inform Forum strategy; responses are read and will guide work next year; most questions are optional), and it is transparent about logistics and scope. However, it offers little empirical evidence about the survey's impact (no response rates, no concrete examples of decisions driven by prior survey results beyond a linked strategy post), and even notes low engagement with last year’s results. It therefore gives a plausible but weakly substantiated justification: reasonable and clear, but lacking data on representativeness, past effectiveness, or how responses will be used in practice.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: The post’s empirical claims are verifiable and accurate. The EA Forum post itself (Aug 6, 2025) states the dates, optional questions, estimated time, browser-saved answers, shorter flow for people who haven’t visited in 12 months, and the planned close date (Aug 20). The linked survey form (forms.cea.community) confirms “All questions are optional,” the browser-save/pause note, and an estimated ~15 minutes completion time. The post’s claim that last year’s survey informed the Forum strategy is supported by the Jan 2025 Forum strategy post, which explicitly cites survey data in its appendix. The 2023 survey-results post (Jul 26, 2024) shows the 609 responses and low engagement metrics referenced. Minor caveats: internal claims such as “we read every response” or whether the survey was left open longer than Aug 20 are assertions from CEA/Forum staff and are not independently verifiable from public pages beyond those posts; branching logic (a ‘‘significantly shorter survey’’ for non‑users) is strongly implied by the form content but exact question flow can only be fully confirmed by interacting with the live form.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Missing direct survey link (major usability issue). The post says “Take the survey” but doesn’t include a clickable URL or button. Add the full survey URL and a prominent button/anchor near the top (and a plain-text link for people who can’t open the button). This is the single most important fix — without it, readers can’t act. 

2) Be explicit about privacy, data handling, and reporting. Say whether responses are anonymous, who on CEA/Forum will see raw answers, how long data will be kept, and whether/when you’ll publish aggregated results or raw data. If you plan to publish a summary post (you mention wanting to), commit to a timeline and describe what will be reported. Readers often care whether their feedback is private and how it will be used. 

3) Strengthen the call-to-action and clarity on impact. Briefly state (in one sentence) what decisions you expect to make from this survey and why responding is worth 10–20 minutes. Clarify who you especially want to hear from (active posters, lurkers, newcomers), and add the survey close time zone for the August 20 deadline. These small additions increase response rates and reduce confusion.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies three high-impact, actionable issues: the missing direct survey link is a major usability/activation failure (readers can’t respond), privacy/data-handling details are commonly expected and affect willingness to participate, and a clearer CTA (what decisions will follow, target respondents, and exact timezone for the deadline) will raise response rates. These fixes are critical yet short and wouldn’t bloat the post. Not a 9–10 because the problems aren’t existential (they’re fixable and not conceptually wrong), but they are important and the reviewer flags the right priorities.
